title: Mate 10 Pro audio through the included dongle?

thread.text:
So there's a new video  
up from PocketNow where Jaime Rivera talks about the Mate 10 Pro. He basically says that he loves the phone, but mentions that the audio through the dongle is "bad". Is this true, and if so, what's bad about it? Does it sound overall flat, or get distorted at higher volumes? Can the same be said about the headphone jack? I listen to music a lot, so I'd like to have great sounding headphone audio on my next phone, but I'm having a hard time choosing between the LG V30, HTC U11+ (or 12+), S9+ with Dolby Atmos, or Mate 10 Pro. The Mate is on my list for the apparent phenomenal battery life, obviously, which is another important thing on my list. Incidentally, I have heard that other dongles like the one included with the Razer phone are compatible with the Pro, and that one in particular is a great one. Any thoughts on this?
I also have difficulty deciding between the regular Mate 10 and the Pro. I like the idea of having a fingerprint scanner on the front for navigation and the ability to use the phone on a desk, but besides that and the headphone jack, I'm a bit wary of the LCD screen as opposed to AMOLED. Although the effect on overall battery endurance is probably marginal, there is a difference between the two, according to GSMArena's review. Plus, coming from a Nexus 6P, having a phone with a water-resistance and a screen I can actually see at max brightness in direct sunlight is appealing. If only Huawei had made ONE phone without such curious compromises... I'm honestly torn.

I had the P10 before and the audio through wired headphones was really bad so I didn't hold much hope for the Mate 10 Pro but I've been very pleasantly surprised. When connected to wired headphones the phone's equaliser is also activated so you can fine tune the sound to your liking too and I've been happy with mine

replies.text: I'd have preferred the FPS on the front too like the regular Mate 10 has but you lose the Amoled screen and more importantly to me Always On Display

replies.text: Notifications are way too important to me to miss. Even from the mundane apps I like to still be updated on them so if I couldn't have that I'd have ditched my Mate 10 Pro promptly. Huawei are very aggressive with them and battery optimisations so have many background tasks and Notifications turned off or at least managed by the software by default so knowing that your first port of call is going into those settings and enabling them. When I set mine up the first thing I did was enable all notifications on Lockscreen, all apps to be ignored by battery optimisation and all apps to run in the background. This way you get all your notifications and if anything is eating the battery in the background you'll soon get a prompt telling you an app is consuming a lot of power and you can deal with them one by one til you get a good balance to suit your own needs.

thread.text:
It's to do with Huawei's battery optimisation, it's aggressive which means you need to pay with the optimisation settings to ensure you get notifications through ok.
I've seen others on this forum say after a bit of time they've managed to change the correct settings to ensure they get notifications through ok.
Hopefully one of those guys can reply to your thread and let you know (and me) how to do that!

I'm positive it worked fine on my P10 I had last year so maybe just a software bug that will be addressed in an update?
Turn off power intensive prompt in your notifications apps and emails to get yours thru and bypass the aggressive battery management.

On XDA someone suggested to open the app having the notification problems and then when you tap on the recent apps icon you can click the locking icon for the app in the tabbed list. THis might help also by preventing EMUI from shutting down the application. YMMV

title: Mate 10/Pro Users, What do you like/not like about EMUI?

thread.text:
Hi everyone,
So I've narrowed my choices for my next phone between the LG V30+ and the Mate 10 Pro. Obviously, with the 4,000 mAh battery, I'm assuming battery life and standby time on the Mate 10 Pro is a non-issue, as is the screen legibility in direct sunlight. My other two concerns are the sound through the dongle with a pair of quality, high impedance earbuds ( I'm considering the V30+ for the quad DAC) and the software.
I've seen a lot of people down EMUI, due to it's supposed "redundancy". My father has a Mate 9, so I have very little experience with EMUI, other than setting the phone up for him. Visually, it's an obvious copy of iOS, which I actually don't mind. In fact, I prefer the EMUI/ iOS folder icons, that allow you to view nine apps per folder. To me, it's a much cleaner look. But aside from that, what are the things you like and dislike about EMUI? Are your dislikes just little annoyances or deal breakers? How do you get around it?
I'm coming from a Nexus 6P, so I tried but I'm quite bored with stock, so I'm looking for a more feature-packed replacement again. I'd put the S9+ on my list of options, but Samsung's battery life apparently continues to suck, so that's a no go. What are your opinions? Should I go for the Mate 10 Pro, or the LG V30+, which apparently has similarly stellar battery life? Feedback is appreciated.

title: Coming back to Android to a Huawei mate 10 pro after year with IPhone 7 plus

thread.text:
Hi all
I have been away from Android for a year to try out Apple ecosystem on the IPhone 7 plus. The good points of iOS were the simplicity and fluidity of the software working alongside the hardware. Also timely updates but I missed the Android customisation.
To cut things short my wife needed a new phone so I have decided to pass her my iPhone 7 plus and jump back on the Android bandwagon.
After researching extensively for all the flagships I was almost decided on the Galaxy note 8 but a friend of mine recommended the Huawei mate 10 pro and seeing it's cheaper price coupled with some excellent hardware and software optimisation especially the AI Kirin chip.
So I pulled the trigger and ordered one from Carphone Warehouse with delivery on Monday and am super excited to use my first bezelless display phone with the new 18.9 ratio and hopefully excellent battery life to name the many features.
Let me know of how some of you Mate 10 pro owners are finding it especially after some months of usage. I have been told unlike Samsung which has a tendency to slow down after a few months with Lag issues. The Kirin chip because of the AI will keep it optimised for best usage for a lot longer.
Thanks in advance for the advice.
😀

Though I don't own a Mate 10 Pro I think it's a great choice. Best battery life in comparison to the most recent flagships. Best camera that incorporates manual/pro mode. Beautiful looking phone too. 
Regardless of the quality of the photos that i take on my V30, the wide angle has been amazing. I mention that because i can't give up the wide angle. If I could i would choose the Mate 10 Pro.

I've felt the same this time around too and over the past week or so that I've had it I've had to go work my way through any little niggles or annoyances with battery management and Notifications but I'm pretty much there now and Notifications are flawless now and the battery is getting me through an entire day which for me being a seriously heavy user is very impressive. The Note 8 I had before it was decent always needed another top up on the charger around dinner time. Like I said already, Huawei phones just need a little more fine tuning to your needs unlike most other devices where the settings are pretty much set to most users needs already. I go through way too many phones and usually switch every 3-6 months but I already feel like this could be the first phone to last me at least a year. I'm hoping it lasts me 2 years but I won't even try making that commitment right now.
As for the alarm clock, it's ok but I always switch to Google Clock on my phones because I like the various options it gives and it's never let me down

title: Possible to block all app notifications on lock screen??

thread.text:
This is driving me nuts. I love the always-on time, date, and battery status. No more turning the phone on for that info. However, lock screen app notifications are a complete deal breaker for me. Hiding "sensitive content," while still showing what app the notification comes from doesn't go far enough. Is there any way to completely get rid of this WITHOUT losing notifications in the notifications bar or is the only solution to get rid of the M10 and go back to an earlier version of Android? I don't need everyone within eyesight to know everything that's going on with my phone.
Sorry for the rant...

No experience on a Huawei, but on a Samsung you can go to settings>lockscreen>notifications>content. That will give you 3 options: show notifications, hide content, do not show notifications. Maybe you could look into your settings?
Settings> Apps & Notifications > Notifications Management > click the 3 dots in the top right corner > Lock Screen notifications > select 'do not display notifications'
You'll get the same 3 option menu Chanchan05 mentioned above
That took care of most of them but even with those settings a few are still showing up.

I have the mate 10 pro. The phone itself is very good. As far as the phone goes. Its super fast. for what i do. photos, msging, I stream epl games sometimes via optus subscription. and cricket. I have used it on netflix and worked well. Screen quality is great. photos are awesome.

thread.text:
It's linked because then what's the point of the fingerprint? It becomes just a button. The FP reader is only active if you have a secure screen lock or for secure transactions/unlocks within apps. 
You can use Android Auto and it will accept voice commands while driving.

replies.text:
Oh that's a bummer 
How to activate android auto? For instance if I want to make a call or send a text message

There are a few ways to do this. 
1) If your audio system supports it. Most cars with phone functions can let you text and call using voice with their built-in system. The 'how', however, depends on your system, but usually pressing the command button and saying 'Message CONTACT' or something like that works. 
2) If your phone supports audio commands while driving. Some devices have a 'Driving Mode' that helps with this, but it needs to be activated from the settings. Not all devices have it, however. 
3) Android Auto. Just download the app from the Play Store, install, and either open it manually or have it run automagically when you're in your car. It'll show a simplified screen for quick shortcuts but will also work with voice commands while driving as if you were using Google's Assistant.

thread.text: I don't think that is possible at All

Don't know if this will solve your issue, but I just found a third party screen lock app that let's me use fingerprint unlock WITHOUT entering a PIN. I have a PIN set as a backup, but all I do now is touch the fingerprint scanner and my phone unlocks no matter what method I use to lock (turn off) the screen. I hated how the only way was to lock with the power button (or natural time out settings, not very convenient obviously), and if I went to wake up my device using the proximity sensor, it would force me to use my PIN. Turns out this is not a Samsung issue, it's a DEVELOPER issue, in that they failed to incorporate this unlock method into their apps. But I found an app that will work, called 'Hi Locker'. Free with a paid pro version ($1.99). Highly customizable and lots of features, or you an just use what you need to use. Hope this helped.

Oh no, it looks like I'll have to part with my Huawei Mate 10 pro due to a camera setting. The resolution setting for 16. 9 is just not there. I can see settings for 4.3 and 18.9 but no 16.9. This is causing problems when I want to edit the photos into my videos with Adobe. It is the strangest thing.
I've have Googled it ad nauseum ad infinito with no luck. 
I went into a store today where they sell the sake model and had a look in the settings and bingo, the 16.9 was there. 
This post is my last ditch attempt to get some help, so I won't have to part with my phone.

Hi all,
I already have a Nexus 6P from Huawei that I'm using on T-Mobile prepaid here in the U.S. that I'm looking to upgrade from, but I'm having difficulty deciding what to get. The Mate 10 and Mate 10 Pro are on my short list, but I have a few questions about both for those of you that have one or the other. I'd appreciate some honest feedback. For informational purposes, I'm a female with smaller hands.
First, I stream my music often on Google Play Music, and I listen through earbuds (with a mic, of course). How is the audio quality through the headphone jack on the Mate 10 / dongle on the 10 Pro? Is it comparable to the quad DAC on the LG V30 or HTC's BoomSound? In truth, BoomSound is my favorite audio implementation. Even with my current 32 ohm impedance earbuds, the sound quality is fantastic. By contrast, when I tested my earbuds on the V30, there was no difference in the sound, whether the DAC setting was togged on or off. Apparently, the quad DAC on the V30 is triggered on by a headset of at least 50 ohm impedance, as shown in [this video](

). Do any of you have eperience with these phones that can compare the quality of sound on the Mate 10?
Second, how is the battery life and standby time on the Mate 10 with the LCD screen? I've only used phones with AMOLED screens, and even though LCDs give more realistic colors, I'm concerned that they're more power-hungry than AMOLED, due to the fact that LCD uses backlight, where all pixels are lit up. Is there a discernible difference between the two? I don't consider myself a heavy user, really. All I do is talk, text, stream my music, occasionally browse the web, watch YouTube videos, and visit forums. I don't do anything graphic intensive like gaming, nor am I big into photography, other than the occasional point-and-shoot. As such, excellent standby is a must.
Third, how is the screen visibility in outdoor light, especially in direct sunlight? My major gripe with the 6P is that visibility of the screen in direct sun is NIL. No amount of squinting or cupping my hand over the screen helps. So which of the two Mate 10's has the better screen?
I will admit that although the fingerprint scanner on my 6P is on the back and in a natural position for my finger to rest, the prospect of a front scanner where I don't have to constantly pick up the phone to unlock it is intriguing.
As far as EMUI goes, I can readily admit to it being somewhat of a rip off of iOS, but since I don't hate Apple, and I actually like and prefer the look of the 9 apps in each folder, I don't mind. Yeah, it's probably me being picky, but I hate only being able to see 4 apps in a folder. The EMUI iOS-like folder setup just looks cleaner and more organized to me.
My best friend keeps telling me I should just go for the Note 8, but I haven't had a Samsung phone since the S3. TouchWiz, Samsung Experience, or whatever they're calling it now scares me. The sad part is, though, when it comes to accessories, Apple and Samsung get the most support in the way of choices, as well as the ability to take either phone to any local shop and know you can have it repaired without a lot of hassle. But I've never been one to follow the herd.
Anyway, what do all of you think? Apologies for the long-winded post, but I don't take spending $1000+ when all is said and done lightly. I'd like to make as informed a decision and purchase as I can. Thanks in advance for your help.

title: New battery charge percentage, what should it be?

thread.text:
Hi all, this may seem like a strange question. 
Just got a new Mate 10 Pro, and when I switched it on for the first time the battery percentage was at 42%. I've read somewhere that as a general rule for new phones, batteries are normally between 50 and 60% out of the box, and if it is anything less this could be a sign that the battery is faulty (e.g. can't hold charge for long). Also my last few phones have actually been around 50-60%, so was a little concerned to see it at 42%.
Does anyone know if this is true or what I've read is a load of rubbish?

Thanks.

title: Does the pro have full device encryption like most phones now? The 9 did not

thread.text:
One thing that caused me concern on my Mate 9 was that it did not use full device encryption. I even contacted Huawei and they told me it did not but I could use their vault app (or whatever it was called) to store private data.
With all these concerns about China's spying, etc., seems like something they should have to prove everyone wrong.
Anyone know if the 10 will have it? (like the Galaxy phones, the pixels, etc. etc.)

How is that even possible given that Google absolutely requires all Android 6.0+ devices to not only support full device encryption but also have it enabled by default.
The Mate 9 was released with 6.0, right? And it was Google certified - so it has to have been fully encrypted. How would it get a Google certification without?

replies.text:
I don't know. I seem to recall it said nowhere in the settings that it was encrypted. That's what caused me concern. I contacted Huawei and they basically confirmed that and told me I could use their vault if I wanted to protect any information. I was thinking exactly what you were. I can't confirm that Google -requires- that for certification to use the Gapps. 
Unless it was some sort of major language misunderstanding. I did not get that sense.

thread.text:
https://yourtechexplained.com/2016/1...ed-encryption/
I just looked it up, the Mate 9 shipped with Nougat. It's using FBE with near certainty.
Or it would have been denied Google certification and therefore Play Store access.
The same goes for the Mate 10 (Pro).
It's incredibly likely that the support agent simply didn't know what they were talking about.

I just explained the difference between FBE and FDE and why your support agent most likely had no clue what they are taking about.
But my explanation included a link and some over eager bot deleted it.

replies.text: What does the acronym "FBE" mean?

thread.text:
Oh got it.
Here is another discussion saying the same thing but in more detail than I have:https://forum.xda-developers.com/mat...ption-t3515229
And dug up my original post which included a comment from someone basically dismissing the need for encryption... which is concerning in itself.https://forums.androidcentral.com/hu...-mate-9-a.html

Many Huawei customers are idiots and sadly Huawei's customer support isn't well informed. I wouldn't put any weight on the words of a single CSR.
Yes, EMUI doesn't expose the encryption status to consumers - which is indeed worrisome and a problem in itself.
But I'm reasonably certain that both the Mate 9 and 10 simply use Nougat's and Oreos default file based encryption for the sole reason that Google wouldn't or at the very least shouldn't certify their devices for official Play Store access otherwise. But Google did.

Att will unlock it once you meet all their unlock criteria
Eligibility requirements
Wireless, business & non-AT&T customers
Requirements for unlocking AT&T phones, tablets, and mobile hotspots.
Your device isn’t reported lost or stolen, or involved with fraud.You must complete your contract or installment plan (including early termination fees). Or, pay off an installment plan early and then make another unlock request in 24 hours.Your device isn’t active on another AT&T account.If you upgraded early, wait 14 days to unlock your old device. Business customers wait 30 days.Your service must be active for at least 60 days with no past due or unpaid balance.AT&T PREPAIDSM (formerly GoPhone®) devices must have at least 6 months of active service.If you’re military, we’ll ask you to email your TCS or PCS (Temporary / permanent change of station) documents for eligibility. You won’t have to complete installment plans or contracts.If you have a business-owned device, your company must authorize you to unlock it.

AT&T reserves the right to deny any unlock request that it concludes would result in an abuse of this policy or is part of an effort to defraud AT&T or its customers. AT&T further reserves the right to alter this unlocking policy at its discretion without advance notice. If during any one month, more than 100 requests are made from a single source, and if more than 10% of those requests are duplicate IMEI numbers, AT&T will no longer process unlock requests from that source.

thread.text:
Here's a few thoughts from my first 2 days of usage:
- The fingerprint scanner is lightening fast and it hasn't failed to authenticate once yet.
- Battery life appears to be above average but not amazing like everyone was expecting from a 4000mAh battery, though it does charge exceptionally quickly.
- As expected from EMUI, there's a tonne of bloatware.
- Annoyingly, there's no double-tap screen on, or that setting the 6P had where you point the screen at your face and it recognises you're looking at it so turns on (can't remember the name for it, and I'm not talking about face unlocking like iris scan etc), so literally the only way to wake your screen is to press the power button (or unlock with fingerprint scanner). Not very convenient though if you just want to quickly check the time and the phone is on a flat surface.
- As a result of the above, I have turned on AOD. This is tucked away in settings and you have to search for it (as far as I'm aware)
- Notifications are a bit of a conundrum, they disappear when you unlock the phone and then lock it again despite not reading them. I'd still expect some form of notification to display to remind me I still have unread notifications.
- The notification light is very small and often difficult notice when it's flashing.
- Call and notification volume are linked so you cannot alter these 2 separately without the use of a third party app.
- My biggest qualm at the minute is trying to swipe down. This could just be me and it will no doubt improve over time but I am often finding that when I swipe down, unless I'm really concentrating to make a perfect vertical swipe, it often mistakes it for a side swipe. Furthermore, when trying to swipe down to view your notifications, unless you are literally swiping down from the top of the screen, it mistakes this swipe for another which takes you into a search for settings screen, this is extremely frustrating.
I does sound like I'm really hammering the phone to be fair but these are all minor issues and could be completely irrelevant for other users, I had a few teething problems on my Nexus 6P when I first got that and grew to love it. Apart from the above points it really does seem to be a great phone, hopefully some of the points I've been mentioned could be ironed out in a software update as well.
Anyway, sorry for rambling on...just wanted to hear thoughts from anyone else who has the phone and see if they're experiencing any of the same issues?
Cheers

title: Mate 10 Pro Camera - Auto Flash Issue?

thread.text:
Just got a Mate 10 Pro. In general the camera seems really good.
One thing which seems odd is that for me when I put the flash in auto mode, the flash only seems to come on when it's pretty much pitch black (less than 1 lux by looks of it).
I'm on the UK BLA-L09 model on a 8.0.0.115 firmware.
Pictures with the flash when I force the flash on in dark places like this are way better.
Seems the auto flash poss isn't working properly.
Seems the same after restart and also using 3rd party camera apps as well.
Same also after factory reset.
I took two pics in same environment which was very dark.
The one which didn’t use the flash in Auto flash mode seems to be trying to take at 1/4 Sec @ ISO 1230 F1.6
Picture looks terrible and the camera tells me "Sharpening the photo. Please Steady the device”
Using the manual flash then resulted in a picture using settings of 1/50th Sec @ ISO 160 F1.6. Way sharper, in focus, and way less noise.
Now I don't mind a bit of grain and higher ISO to get a good picture, but to me asking us to manage with no flash when selecting 1/4 Second exposure time doesn't seem right does it?
Anyone else seeing this basically auto flash only coming on in close to pitch black, or have I got one with a dud sensor in the camera module?

replies.text:
It definitely will, the Battery is still in it's settling in period it will take quite a few more charge cycles to be fully optimized.
Today I plan on running it all the way down to 0%.
I must say I am truly impressed with the device overall, not quite as refined as the Note8 but still incredibly well built in terms of both software and hardware. The Software is good, very fast and smooth around the UI, and very well optimized. This thing has 6GB RAM, yet barely if ever uses more than 2.6GB RAM even when heavily multitasking, it gets down to about 2.9GB free RAM, basically it hardly uses more than half of what is available.
I have not yet gamed on it but do have Asphalt installed so I'll be giving it a go between today and tomorrow.
I am confident that it will handle the Memory side of gaming very well, but we will have to see how this Kirin970 CPU and Mali G72 12core GPU work under very heavy load.
The phone barely ever gets warm or hot, even with the incredibly fast Huawei Super Charger fast charging it. Even using the Camera heavily does not seem to create too much heat, although it does take a hit on the battery which I guess is to be expected as the Camera is very powerful with f/1.6 Cameras and the NPU doing a lot of work to identify what you are capturing.

All phones battery drains fast under camera usage, the quickst was my G4 and S7 Edge, the Mate 9 just lasts and lasts...
Good to know that about the mate 10, one thing i really like, is that there is minimal or zero throttling when playing heavy cpu games, like Tekken 6, it barely works on any samsung device, due to their DVFS throttling bull****.

title: My Review of the Mate 10 Pro

thread.text:
For those who can't watch the video...
I only really started to give their phones a try starting with the Mate 9 (other than the Nexus 6P if course). Was pretty impressed with it and went on to get the P10 too. So naturally, interested to try the Mate 10 pro too.
For me no SD card and 3.5mm isn't a deal breaker since i'm on mostly cloud and wireless earphones. Then it has Ip67 too. Which is why I chose the pro instead.
The screen is really good as expected from Huawei. The resolution is a bit lower compare to mate 10 or like the S8+, V30, but it's good enough looking. nice colours, contrast, outdoor visibility. The tradeoff is probably worth it since I value battery life more.
Performance is really good. But not sure if it's just Oreo being too new, the software doesn't seem as polished and smooth as the Mate 9. So might take a few updates to get up to speed. But of course still hard to match Pixel 2's fluidity. Huawei's chipset has been impressive in my time with it, with great gaming performance from the Mali GPU. Last year's Mate 9 had one of the best gaming performance on an Android phone. It doesn't feel any better, but it's still great.
Battery life is great too as you would expect from 4000mAh and FHD screen. Easily last me through a day of heavy use, and maybe a bit more the next day. Definitely no complaints here. And impressive how they squeezed in a much larger battery in a phone smaller than the Pixel 2XL.
Before you say the stereos speakers, yes, the Pixel 2 XL is probably louder, but the Mate 10 Pro is no slouch too. it uses the call speaker to supplement bottom speaker too and sounds great still.
Camera wise is going to be really subjective. The image processing is more contrast-y, more textures, going for a more artistic flair? Kinda like Leica's cameras? It's certainly different from what we typically considered good like the higher dynamic range, sharpened images from Samsung, Google, or Apple. I think it looks artsy and nice, and the monochrome mode is definitely fun to shoot with. Overall I like the camera experience here. But I definitely wouldn't blame you for not liking it.
Sounds great so far? here comes the not so great stuff. EMUI. It's not just because i like stock android, but it's because I think the design is all over the place. Samsung on the other hand has cleaned up their act and placed a lot of effort at making their design work, and on the S8 it looks nice actually.
So yeah. Great hardware, maybe less great software. So while this phone isn't at the top of my recommendations list, I wouldn't stop anyone from buying one either if they really like how it looks. And the midnight blue version that I have, really looks darn good.

replies.text: Nice review, a bit sad to hear that emui still isn't streamlined though

With regards to the Samsung skin, it does lag over time. Huawei EMUI doesn't lag nearly as faster or much at all. At least for me. Even if Samsung software is more polished, it won't stay fluid after a while.

Looking on the internet for the next phone isn't a thing except for the minority of the tech inclined. People here save up money, then walk to a shop and see the best bang for buck they can get. Overwhelming majority of the people go prepaid on their networks too. It's a running joke sometimes here that people have nice phones but no credits for data, calls or sms. Lol. But going prepaid means buying phones outright, and preorder prices are higher than buying when the thing has arrived, so people tend to wait like at least 2mos after release. To be honest, even iPhone fans here call people who line up at Apple Stores to get the latest iPhone stupid. That doesn't happen here as much as it does in other countries.
To be honest that's why sometimes I'm envious of other countries getting lots of freebies lol. I know it's a bit oversaid, but a headphone jack. It really bothered me how last year they made fun of apples 'courage' and then they did the same thing. I use my headphones daily, often when my phone is charging. I don't want to lose that functionality or pay extra for a dongle. I do accept that sooner or later they'll probably disappear from most phones (like the removable battery) and I'll have to make do then, but not yet!
I prefer the way the mate 9 looks and like what I've seen from leaks for the mate 10.
With the Honor 9 they improved audio quality, hoping something similar comes to the mate 10.
Battery life will be stellar with the mate 10.
The Kirin 970 will set the bench mark for how quick processors need to be for 2018. Considering the 960 is a year old and still a top tier processor is impressive. 
The mate 10 is also likely to be cheaper, and have expandable memory, which if you work in the countryside like I do, is essential for storing music etc. There isn't good enough signal for streaming. 
All in all I've had a honor 8 for the last year and it has easily been the most reliable phone I've ever had. It works well all the time. Much better than my s7 I had before.
The only area that Huawei/honor need to really step it up (in my view) is the speed and frequency of security patches and general updates.

Huawei will launch a new member of the Mate series in the second half of each year, and in the next few months, Mate 9's successor -- Huawei Mate 10 will debut. At present, Huawei did not disclose any information about this new machine, so all the rumors about this phone have to be elegant. According to the latest news, HUAWEI Mate 10 mobile phone will use a borderless display.
Nowadays, many of the sale, or the upcoming high-end Android phones are using a borderless display, and this configuration has become the industry's latest trend, and in the future, this design trend is also likely spreading to the mid-range of mobile phone field.
As a result, there is no doubt that the Huawei Mate10 will be equipped with the borderless display, but we still do not know the size of its display size. According to speculation, Huawei MATE 10 screen size should be more than 5.0 inch.
On other configurations, this phone will carry with 10nm Huawei Kirin 970 processor. And its fingerprint reader is placed at the front below the display, and running Android 7.0 Nougat system.
In addition, there are news that Huawei Mate 10 will use dual cameras at both front and back cameras. This feature will surely let the machine stand out.
